title: Is spoken poetry about love using figures of speech? - Quora

response.answer_text: All poems convey meaning in ways that are different from everyday, literal language. This kind of meaning is called “connotation”. We use the language of connotation every day - but nowhere near as much as a poet does. For example, today, I heard a student say to another, “Man up, won’t you!”. The speaker was a girl… “Non-literal” or “figurative” meaning (as in “figures of speech”) is at the heart of poetic language, essentially one thing is said, but something else is meant.

Spoken or written, about love or any other topic, some poems have figures of speech in them and some do not. Richard Nordquist has a wonderful list of figures of speech in the http://About.com website.
Written and spoken poetry can be about love and any other topic, using figures of speech and nonfigurative language.
